segments.en: Linked Discourses 36
1. With Verses
8. The Infirmary (2nd)

segments.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā vesāliyaṃ viharati mahāvane kūṭāgārasālāyaṃ.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṃ paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena gilānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
segments.en: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the infirmary, where he sat down on the seat spread out,
and addressed the mendicants:
“Mendicants, a mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.
This is my instruction to you.
And how is a mendicant mindful?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ;
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.
They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
They meditate observing an aspect of the mind …

segments.pli: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā, vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṃ.
segments.en: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of desire and aversion for the world.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sato hoti.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant is mindful.
And how is a mendicant aware?

segments.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti … pe … bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
segments.en: It’s when a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.

segments.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sampajāno hoti.
segments.en: That’s how a mendicant is aware.

segments.pli: Sato, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sampajāno kālaṃ āgameyya.
segments.en: A mendicant should await their time mindful and aware.
This is my instruction to you.

segments.pli: Tassa ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno evaṃ satassa sampajānassa appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato uppajjati sukhā vedanā.
segments.en: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if pleasant feelings arise, they understand:
‘A pleasant feeling has arisen in me.

segments.pli: sā ca kho paṭicca, no appaṭicca.
segments.en: That’s dependent, not independent.
Dependent on what?
Dependent on this very contact.

segments.pli: Ayaṃ kho pana phasso anicco saṅkhato paṭiccasamuppanno.
segments.en: But this contact is impermanent, conditioned, dependently originated.

segments.pli: Aniccaṃ kho pana saṅkhataṃ paṭiccasamuppannaṃ phassaṃ paṭicca uppannā sukhā vedanā kuto niccā bhavissatī’ti.
segments.en: So how could a pleasant feeling be permanent, since it has arisen dependent on contact that is impermanent, conditioned, and dependently originated?’

segments.pli: So phasse ca sukhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassī viharati, vayānupassī viharati, virāgānupassī viharati, nirodhānupassī viharati, paṭinissaggānupassī viharati.
segments.en: They meditate observing impermanence, vanishing, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in contact and pleasant feeling.

segments.pli: Tassa phasse ca sukhāya ca vedanāya aniccānupassino viharato, vayānupassino viharato, virāgānupassino viharato, nirodhānupassino viharato, paṭinissaggānupassino viharato yo phasse ca sukhāya ca vedanāya rāgānusayo, so pahīyati.
segments.en: As they do so, they give up the underlying tendency for greed for contact and pleasant feeling.

segments.pli: Tassa ce, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno evaṃ satassa … pe …
segments.en: While a mendicant is meditating like this—mindful, aware, diligent, keen, and resolute—if painful feelings arise …
if neutral feelings arise, they understand:
‘A neutral feeling has arisen in me.

segments.pli: sā ca kho paṭicca, no appaṭicca.
segments.en: That’s dependent, not independent.
Dependent on what?
Dependent on this very contact.
(Expand in detail as in the previous discourse.)

segments.pli: Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’

segments.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, telañca paṭicca vaṭṭiñca paṭicca telappadīpo jhāyeyya,
segments.en: Suppose an oil lamp depended on oil and a wick to burn.

segments.pli: tasseva telassa ca vaṭṭiyā ca pariyādānā anāhāro nibbāyeyya;
segments.en: As the oil and the wick are used up, it would be extinguished due to lack of fuel.

segments.pli: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘kāyapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti. Jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayamāno ‘jīvitapariyantikaṃ vedanaṃ vedayāmī’ti pajānāti.
segments.en: In the same way, feeling the end of the body approaching, a mendicant understands: ‘I feel the end of the body approaching.’ Feeling the end of life approaching, they understand: ‘I feel the end of life approaching.’

segments.pli: ‘Kāyassa bhedā uddhaṃ jīvitapariyādānā idheva sabbavedayitāni anabhinanditāni sītībhavissantī’ti pajānātī”ti.
segments.en: They understand: ‘When my body breaks up and my life is over, everything that’s felt, since I no longer take pleasure in it, will become cool right here.’”

sections.title: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī,…

suttaplex.blurb: A mendicant should await their death mindful and aware. They should bear the feelings of approaching death with wisdom and equanimity.
